wikipedia_page.main: William Thomson (1760 – November 1806) was an English mineralogist, who used the name Guglielmo Thomson in Italy in later life. He died in Palermo at the age of 46 years.

response: * William Thomson (military officer) (1727–1796), American militia captain in Capture of Savannah
* William Thomson (Solicitor General), Solicitor General for England and Wales, 1717–1720
* William Thomson (politician) (1818–1866), Member of Parliament in Christchurch, New Zealand
* William Thomson (writer) (1746–1817), Scottish minister and historian
* William Thomson (bishop) (1819–1890), Archbishop of York, 1862–1890
* William Thomson (mineralogist) (1760–1806), English physician and geologist
* William Thomson (physician) (1802–1852), Scottish author and professor of medicine
* William Thomson, 1st Baron Kelvin (1824–1907), Scots-Irish physicist
* William Thomson (Dumbarton footballer) (fl. 1892–1898), Scottish footballer (Dumbarton, Scotland)
* William Thomson (Dundee footballer) (1874–1917), Scottish footballer (Dundee, Bolton Wanderers, Scotland)
* William Thomson (rugby union) (1880–1942), Scottish international rugby union player
* William Thomson (musicologist) (died 1753), Scottish folk song collector and singer
* William Thomson (mathematician) (1856–1947), Scottish mathematician
* Gibbs–Thomson effect – Josiah Willard Gibbs and three Thomsons: James Thomson, William Thomson, 1st Baron Kelvin, Joseph John "J. J." Thomson
* Joule–Thomson effect (a.k.a. Joule–Kelvin effect) – James Prescott Joule and William Thomson, 1st Baron Kelvin
* Kelvin wave – William Thomson, 1st Baron Kelvin
* Kelvin–Helmholtz mechanism, instability – William Thomson, 1st Baron Kelvin and Hermann von Helmholtz
* Kelvin–Joule effect (a.k.a. Joule–Thomson effect) – William Thomson, 1st Baron Kelvin and James Prescott Joule
* Kelvin–Voigt material, model – Woldemar Voigt and William Thomson, 1st Baron Kelvin
* Thomson cross-section, effect – William Thomson, 1st Baron Kelvin

response: *Widmanstätten patterns, named after Count Alois von Beckh Widmanstätten in 1808, but previously reported by William Thomson (mineralogist) in 1804.
